LeadPara.Para: Opposition eyes rural voters as BN tackles land agency scandals

The Malaysian opposition parties in the last general election captured most urban constituencies and many semi-urban wards with large numbers of ethnic Chinese voters. But the opposition has failed to win many rural Malay seats, especially in the Felda heartland.

TailParas.Para: With the next election just round the corner, the opposition knows the road to federal power passes through Federal Land Development Authority (Felda) plantations that are strongholds of the ruling Barisan Nasional (BN) coalition.

Malaysia's Parliament has 54 constituencies with Felda oil-palm and rubber plantations, out of a total of 222, or nearly a quarter of all seats. To run the government, a simple majority of 112 seats is needed.

The opposition won only six Felda seats in the 2013 polls. Three were won by Parti Islam SeMalaysia (PAS), which has left opposition alliance Pakatan Harapan. The opposition got its seventh Felda seat in 2016 when then Deputy Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin was sacked from Umno. He helped former premier Mahathir Mohamad set up opposition Parti Pribumi Bersatu Malaysia (PPBM) and brought over his Pagoh parliamentary ward in Johor.
Thus, the BN controls 47 of the 54 Felda seats, or 87 per cent.
The opposition is working hard to change this in the next polls. Efforts include Tun Dr Mahathir's forays into Felda villages to woo voters.
There are at least 1.2 million voters from the rural Malay heartland - 9 per cent of Malaysia's 13 million registered voters in the 2013 polls.

"Felda is akin to fixed deposit for the government as the settlers have traditionally voted for Umno," said Mr Mohd Hairy Saad, a PPBM leader in Kedah. "But today... they (the settlers) believe Felda has not helped to solve their problems."
But do not expect the Umno-led BN to sit idly by as the opposition assaults Fortress Felda. It has been trying hard to recover from a series of scandals at the land agency.

Felda has been hit by shocks in recent months, such as the loss of RM146 million (S$49 million) to supposedly start a sturgeon farm, the purchase of hotels at inflated prices, and the illicit transfer of premium land in Kuala Lumpur worth some RM1 billion to a private developer.

Last month, Prime Minister Najib Razak launched Felda 2.0, an initiative to improve incomes and reduce debts incurred by the farmers in developing land. He announced the success of a six-month-old plan to persuade some of the original 112,635 settlers who had gone independent to once again sell their palm oil and rubber harvests through the government. This is a key barometer of support, as over the decades several thousand plantation owners had decided to operate independently.

"After six months since the announcement, 10,338 settlers had decided to return to Felda, making the current number of Felda settlers (who sell through the government) at 105,294, or 93.5 per cent," he said then. "This clearly shows the settlers continued to have faith in Felda and consequently (rubbishes) claims that the settlers were no longer with the government."

Still, politicians and analysts say close attention should be paid to the second-and third-generation family members of the original settlers. The younger ones are more likely to drift away from voting for the government. Their parents and grandparents are naturally grateful to the government, when between 1957 and 1990 they were each given at least 4ha of land to cultivate crops to alleviate Malay rural poverty. These settlers today own 480,000ha of land, with another 420,000ha run commercially by Felda itself.

But many in the second-and third generations work outside the family plantations, and grapple like other Malaysians with cost-of-living issues. They are also exposed to social media debates on matters such as graft in Felda and in state fund 1Malaysia Development Berhad.

"Most of the settlers' children work and live outside Felda settlements. They're exposed to a different environment from their parents and they have access to information via social media," said Mr Hisommudin Bakar, executive director at research outfit Ilham Centre.

He conducted surveys in June and November last year to back his view. The surveys were conducted in six Felda settlements in Pahang and one settlement each in Johor, Negeri Sembilan, Perak and Perlis.

Second-generation Felda farmer Ramli Mat, 36, from Chini 5 settlement in Pahang, said: "Social media really opens up the floodgate of information on the mismanagement of Felda. Whatever information we get now is more diverse and no longer one-sided like before."
Ilham Centre found that some 30 per cent of the original settlers and/or their spouses have died, and most of those still alive are aged above 60.

Some in the younger generation are worried about the debts carried by their elders, who borrowed money from Felda to plant or replant their palm and rubber crops. "I'm worried that this financial burden will snowball and be passed on to my children," said second-generation Felda rubber tapper Zaidi Hashim, 47, who lives in a plantation in Bukit Tangga in Kedah.

Under a re-cultivation scheme, settlers can get government loans to help them replant oil palm every three years. The cost, including clearingland and planting seeds, is between RM7,000 and RM15,000. Most settlers took up the loans.

Mr Mohd Padli Abd Rahman, 40, another rubber tapper, said he and his family had been unwavering in their support for BN, but will vote differently this time. "I'm worried about taking over the land when my parents die and inheriting their debts. There was no strong platform to voice our concerns previously but now there's Tun Mahathir."

Then again, others from the second and third generations, though uneasy with the way things are, might not necessarily vote for the opposition. Second-generation settler Mohamad Norman Maslih, 31, said: "The opposition doesn't get my vote because they can't even agree on seat allocation. If they can't even agree on that, how are they supposed to help Felda?"
